title: Great for mushroom hunting!
text:
I got these to stick in my pack incase I come across edible mushrooms while hiking. They pop up and stay up on their own, but fold down to nothing to fit in your pack. I'm extremely pleased with them for that purpose.

Personally I couldn't stomach keeping a butterfly in one - they're smaller than a shoe box and the butterfly would beat its wings to death on the mesh. Maybe fun for a caterpillar or fireflies or something, and it's so so important for kids to have dirty experiences with the natural world... but parents please don't let these be little starvation cages or let your kid toss them around with creatures in them. That's a terrible lesson to learn more than once.

The quality is meh, but excellent for the price. They seem sturdy enough but the seams are a little sloppy. That's just aesthetic though, they seem up to the task of caging bugs or carrying mushrooms. And 4 for $14?? Can't beat that price! I'm a happy camper.

title: The quintessential ,1/10 scale RC rock crawlin' tire
text:
Noob to scale rc crawling. 20 yr veteran of actual , full-scale rockcrawling. I know all about the rocksport technicalities & handling. It doesn't matter if your crawling a 5500lb ,4 door Jeep on 40s or a 1/10 scale , wide-bodied crawling truggy on 4.75" tires ; the actual rubber tires in both scenarios are going to claim approximately 75%-80% of the effort. The other 20% is made of small , individual skills or options ( line choice, weight distribution, wheelspeed, conditions, driver aptitude, et.al) but I'm just saying this activity is nearly ALL ABOUT THE TIRES.

This is fourth set of tires I've bought for a Vaterra Ascender WB2 K10 from '72. Each have been deficient in some manner but then I sprung for the ones w/ such a reputation . I was not just equally impressed, I was floored . I have bought so many tires over the years. I know 35" -42" bias or radial carcass design, tread behavior, terrain/conditions affects, durability to durometer, on & on. Well, let me just say that these 1/10 scale PItBulls are every bit the same product my pals that run them on real , full size crawler rigs & Jeeps. Even gusset reenforced sidewalls inside !
The 'Alien Snot' compound is otherworldly adhesive when you scrub them down w/ simple green before mounting. You will find they stick to your fingers once rid of the mold residue.
If the RC could escape gravities pull, it would literally climb walls with these tires.

Now that you've tried the others , coughup the small added $ for a set of these. There a reason so many RC guys run them .

title: Great upgrade but watch your nuts!
text:
Absolutely the right replacement for factory plastics. These are a major component due to their location. They round off from repeatedly crawling & ultimately contribute to the skid/slide-ability of your 1/10 scale RC. Highly recommended.

Just be mindful that the diff housing cover bolts are held on back of pumpkin by captured nuts that are recessed within the diff. If you have big-toe sized paddle thumbs like I do , you're not gonna like allowing these captured locknut's to fall out when you remove cover. Just a VERY USEFUL fyi....

title: set of 4 quality scale beadlock for cost of 1 of the namebrand wheels
text: Nice , heavy beadlock for 1/10 scale crawler. 3piece. 6 beveled lock bolts on inside ring , 24 diameter studs on outter ring + the 6 lugs. Good powder coating . Stout. An above average copy of much more costly SS•, wheel but imposter is easily detected by the exp scale crawler who knows their parts. They're def better than the plastic bls that came w my K10 Ascender truggy. Id buy again.

title: How it compares to a real crawler is shocking
text:
OOB, add receiver+shorty battery & go crawl.
I have a full-size , dedicated crawler. I use it only off-road ,towed to trails. The only thing which comes close to mirroring that feeling of technical rocksport that is found when attempting to get a vehicle thru an obstacle where normally you shouldn't be able to get one to go is the scale crawler rc world. Same physics ,same weight & balance considerations, everything. That being said, the closest vehicle choice which comes very close to the exact behavior of a Jeep JKU on 37-40" tires & beefedup , straight axle housings sprung w coilovers is the Vaterra Ascender. It felt the most like my real rig. I got it & am beginning to think it is exceeding my built, scale Jeep. A home run. Vaterra gets if very close to perfect.

title: Really great game. It is very easy to learn the ...
text:
Really great game. It is very easy to learn the rules of the game, yet it is hard to win. The learning curve is steep, but not in the way you'd expect it to be.

I've played probably over 20 games so far and haven't won yet. I've gotten to see the incarnation card perhaps 4 times but haven't won yet. Just gotta keep trying and learning!

Overall, a fun game. The artwork on everything is nice and the game pieces don't feel thin and cheap.

title: Very Fun Game
text:
I preferred them to have a system of going in/retreating that is indicated by something other than cards (since it is harder to hide your actions from wary opponents if you use the cards provided). I replaced those cards with red and blue marbles (red for retreat, blue for bravery [venturing in, haha]).

This game also, unexpectedly, converts into a very fun drinking game. We make it so that the first person who retreats during each round has to take a shot, every person who is driven out by the appearance of two hazards takes one shot each, and the loser at the very end of the game has to take a shot. Sound judgment decreases as inebriation increases! Great!

title: easy to understand directions, easy math, fun addition to game collections
text:
Ha, this is kinda of fun. Love games by Uno (love Uno and Skip-bo best of all), so I had no qualms about giving this Ono a go (cute name, OhNo!). Just have to keep track of the math in any form you feel comfortable, and it is an otherwise easy game to play. As a group, everyone works to keep the discard pile under 99. As an individual, you are out of the game if your play makes the pile 99 or over. Then the remainder of players keep going until one player is left. There are some fun changes like reverse card, draw 2 card, a subtraction card, and the dreaded 99 card (has a couple of rules on how to play it, when not to).

Inexpensive pack of cards. You may like it or may not. My 5 stars is because it has all the cards, game instructions are easy to understand, and it doesnt feel stressful to learn or play. I find it a worthwhile addition to the game shelf. I dont really play card games, but Ive always taken to the Uno brand games.

title: for adults too. Calming. Adorable looking, feels good, smells good.
text:
smells very good- natural lavender- nothing synthetic. Has a calming vibe about it. If using it for yourself, consider keeping it at your desk--makes for a nice break time item- lay across eyes, or just hold it and breath it in. Keep in mind that it is wipe clean only.

Front side is slightly textured, and the back has a brushed sable feel. Cute little sprig of fluffy feathers on top. I have the orange bean bag (is filled with flax), with an owl face. It's cute. I love the color orange, and owls so this was a must have for me. Feels nice to just knead the bag, and occasionally take a deep breath from it

title: 4 pencils, 1 eraser, 1 sharpener, 1 small sketch book, 4 page guide
text:
Not quite what I expected, but still overall pleased.

The included "guided booklet" is a small 2 page, front and back (4 total) guide. Not terrible, just not much of a highlight. If they described it on this page in the same manner as what is on the container, then I would have known. The mini sketch pad is as expected- basic, small flip style. This kit includes 4 pencils, 1 small firm eraser, and a sharpener. All for $8.49, it is a pleasant little kit. I can see grabbing it as an add on to a themed gift, or simply to have it on hand for yourself whenever the mood to doodle strikes. If the "guided booklet" was just a little more robust in what it had to offer, I would be more impressed. Also, the country of origin is not Germany for any of it. There is a sticker over that information, but what I could make out is Indonesia, Ohio USA, and China. So different origins for the different items I guess.

"CONTENTS"
--20 page sketchbook 4" x 6"
--4 graphite pencils (6B, 2B HB, 2H)
--White, latex free eraser
--Pencil sharpener
--4 page instructions

title: 3"x3" set of mixed pattern heart shaped stickers, choose "shinny" if want red VD hearts
text:
There are two options to choose from when selecting heart stickers. One set is shiny, sparkly heart stickers labeled "shinny red" (I think they mean shiny), and the other set, the one I am reviewing is for the mixed color. Take a look at the product pictures to see the difference between the two. Choose wisely.

The mixed color variety is just as pictured. 8 different designs. A roll of 500 total. One has the phrase "thank you" printed on it, which I really like as an option because I often give out little token gifts or notes, and the addition of "thank you" is totally appropriate. The others are simply different patterns in heart shapes. Certainly not limited to Valentines Day. All the others look appropriate to use any time. Nice way to close off a goody bag (candy, baked goods, etc) or a card. The size of the stickers is a little over 3" x 3" so they are a good size!

If you want a more Valentines look, then choose the other "shinny" set, which appears to be just shiny red stickers.

Quality is fine.. it's a sticker. I am not making unnecessary trips going into stores looking for heart stickers, so the convenience of online shopping makes it worth it to me. I think an option that includes both sets would be nice to see and add greater value.

title: solid looking quality game with emphasis on education while looking fun and relevant
text:
I haven't gotten any feedback on this from the people I gave it to.. I would normally not bother with a review, but I thought it looked promising enough that it was worth recommending (even sight unseen, but I at least has opportunity to really look at it eventually, just not play it through). I bought it as a christmas gift for a couple of young boys- ages 10-14ish. Not entirely sure. When I am selecting gifts I always buy games or books for kids, always looking for educational offerings.. and given the theme of this and how it is designed for education in mind.. I thought this one seemed right up their ally. I had read reviews, looked over the details of the game, and while it cost a little more than I would normally spend on a token gift for kids I don't know real well, I thought it was interesting enough sounding to me- and educationally interesting that it would be worth a bit of a splurge (hoping they liked it and benefited from it!). Math, imagination, intrigue, magic, economics, strategy, skill development.. all UNPLUGGED- no need for apps, electronics. Can play under kitchen table light, or by candlelight. *I* thought it sounded fun. I may have to pick up another game for my own use at home.

I also liked the look of the box and the components. The colorful thick cards, bright potions in bottles on a rack, thick play currency.. It just didn't/doesn't look cheap. I was able to look over the materials, and it is a solid looking game. I just didn't have chance to actually play it. I really hope they liked it,and that the parents appreciated it. It seems like a game to hold on to, take care of and use time and time again.

It is because I am considering purchasing again for future gift giving, and have recommended other people to check it out, and that I keep it book marked to come back to, that I am going ahead with a full 5 star rating. It looks good, has quality look and feel, has game play with both education and imagination in mind. Instructions are straightforward- not too awkward or frustrating. The marketplace reminds me of any of the online game play (especially mmos) but all without the need to be attached to electronics.

title: topical phrasing- trash pands, doggo, etc. Looks fun; nice looking game
text:
Looks like a fun game for kids and adults. It is for 2-4 players, ages 8 and up. I bought it as a gift. I don't know if it is complicated or not, but it looked appealing and out of all the other games on here I looked at, I chose this one. I think with games you have to be one to want to learn and play them (I don't) and/or know who you will be playing with- are they patient, receptive to learning, etc.

I bought it as part of a gift for a family with 4 kids of various ages. I bought a few games and this was one of them. I didn't want to spend more than $10 per game, and this fit the bill. Seeing the topical use of "trash pands" and "doggo" make me laugh, so I thought the older kids would like it too. Who knows how relevant it will be in a few years. I do not know if they ever played it or if it is collecting dust somewhere. I thought a couple of the older ones would like the name of the game. I am not into buying toys for kids, usually it is books, games, or project/activities. They seemed to be curious about it and had mentioned that they were getting into playing games like this, so hopefully they have enjoyed it.

I give it a 4 for simply being intriguing looking, sounding fun, well packaged, attractive, current, and seemingly quality game. I figure anything like this is a chance

title: collectors tin addition makes for a nice gift; nice family game
text: Cute little game. I bought it as a gift for a couple of little boys. I figured even if they lose cards, they can still play with the container as this is the collectors addition. Also figured this container would be better than a typical box for storage.  It seemed easy enough to teach, to play. Nice, big colorful graphics. For 2-6 players, ages 6 and up. I think it is fine for any age- not so complicated that a super youngin' wouldn't want to play or watch. Fun enough for whole family, or even just between the children.

title: exercise your brain, keep hands busy, replayable
text:
We keep a bowl full of puzzles like this to offer to people who come over. Gives people something to do. Sometimes I have brought a few with me over to social gatherings to keep me busy, as I am not really inspired to actually talk to people. Also nice to grab a puzzle and work on it during some down time. Basically a little way to exercise the brain.

This set of metal and string puzzles are fairly challenging. They are large enough to provide good view of what needs to be done. The challenge level is considered the "extreme range" and best suited for "gifted or experienced problem solvers". I don't necessarily consider myself either, but I found some were doable, and a couple were frustrating. Either way, I think these are worth the time whether you figure it out or not. I sometimes find that I can solve one, then return to it some time after and have pretty much forgotten how to do it. So it can be played with time and time again, too.

Makes a nice gift- add in some other puzzles like this or puzzle books.

I have not heard any complaints about this product from them, so hopefully they would tell me about it they had problems. I like the tube that is used to help hold the pieces in place while it is being rolled up, it also helps to keep from pieces being damaged. If I get back into doing puzzles, I will be sure to buy this, as I have cats and dogs-- and well, I'm sure they would try to "help" when I am not there.

title: Fun but VERY fragile as it grows and before it dries.
text: My review is similar to the others.  This came with no directions in our kits. We added some glitter before and some after the project was fully dry. We didn't know to add decorations as we started the first time.  The "snow" fell off so easily if even tapped. It was better when it dried well but this is a very fragile project. However, my granddaughter had fun watching the tree grow as the day continued.  But keep it out of "touch"  NO MOVEMENT at all once it begins to grow.

title: I loved it so much that I purchased 5 more
text:
I ordered this item to add to a gift for a little girl. I loved it so much that I purchased 5 more. You really can't beat this for the price. On sale for 8+ dollars. I'm giving to girls ranging from age 6 to 11. My six year old was literally enthralled for hours on end as she reviewed the endless combinations of colors, patterns and accessories for the outfits. She's more if a science kid, so I wasn't sure it would interest her. Her favorite gift this year was a mineral and rock collection. When we were decided which family member would get what, she asked if she could have one.

This would make an excellent party activity for a girls and the kids could take the portfolios home or leave a signed page with the birthday girl.

I'm not much of a trendy fashion girl myself and I abhor anything Barbie-esque for the most part. But I loved the ethnic diversity. Just wish more body types were represented that reflect what women truly look like.

Overall, as a stimulating artistic exercise, I'm very pleased with this purchase.

title: Pros and Cons

title: I feel that this cuda been made quite better, there's only enough
text: While a very cute idea, I feel that this cuda been made quite better, there's only enough. Room for the accessories that it comes with, to put half of most girls Barbie stash in this closet case it would be bulging at the seems... The drawers are kinda difficult to open for small hands and the closet doesn't like to stand up on it's own AND it only fits one Barbie... Upside is my granddaughter loved it as now she has something to take with her on sleepovers... Coming from old school Barbie days this doesn't compare to the old Barbie closets as far as space...

title: Not good for teaching time
text:
[[VIDEOID:5b307be8d442b0a08e8f5290355d7fff]] The product is sturdy and thick not a cheap board. Comes with 2 markers and a string to hang it up.
HOWEVER, this is not a good tool to teach kids time. The hour hand is RED but the line to write the hour in is BLUE and likewise the minute hand is BLUE and the line to write minutes is RED. Very confusing for someone learning to read a clock. Not sure why they thought that was a good idea but my kid kept getting confused so I returned this.

title: Fun to fly, but the camera is crap
text: My wife bought me this for Christmas, and I actually really like the way it flies. It drifts quite a bit and I try to adjust it with the trim settings but can't seem to get it to stand still even in low wind. It is still a lot of fun though and fairly simple to control. The problem with this drone, is the camera! I just don't know what they were thinking. The MicroSD card recording seems like the logical way to go, for two reasons. First, the WiFi signal is weak. So sending video from the drone to your phone using a weak WiFi signal is going to make the video pause when it gets too far from your phone. Second, having the phone mounted on the controller seems to cause interference which also makes the video pause during recording. So when you play the videos back, the timer is counting like it's playing, but the video appears frozen and then skips portions of the video. Epic fail! So I decided to buy a 16gb MicroSD and try my luck with that and ignore the FPV part entirely. Good luck! The video files require VLC because QuickTime won't play them. Some don't seem to record at all. Just overall, not happy with the video part. It's fun to fly and I don't expect much in this price range, but did they even try them before mass producing them? What fun is a drone with a crap camera?

title: A great set for a great price!
text:
This kit is the way to go for those of us on a more average budget. I wanted a good play set for my kids, but I didn't want to pay $5K. I'm not cheap, but if I can save money by doing something myself, I'm going to.

The lumber, all pressure treated, was about $450. We bought this set, a saucer swing (and lumber/supplies) for the other side, a small rock walk kit. We built another A frame in the same dimensions as the one the kit instructions said to make for the saucer swing, I also bought an extra support bracket for the end.

We added solar lights recently too. Total cost, including all the extras, was just about $800. We had everything cut and stained prior to having two friends over to help assemble. It took three adults just about 4 hours to put it together, start to finish, sigh varying levels of skill. My 6 year old and 4 year old love it! Very blessed to have gotten this for them for Christmas right before this pandemic!

Saucer Swing: https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B07QYY4WR4?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title

A Frame Support Bracket: https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B005KUL00O?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title

Rock Wall Kit: https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B01H5VFI8U?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title

title: Cute for notes or art activities
text: This is a cute quick time killer. The pages are thick, you can leave them as single sheets like a notepad or place a small stack together on an included spiral spine (great for when you're on the move). The pages are true to size and came in a thick box with 4 scribble sticks and stickers. The only con is that the black residue rubbed away can add up if multiple pages are used at once (which should be expected). The residue was an easy clean up with no black streaks on the table. We've got a long way to go but I would buy again.

title: Nice product
text: Don't let the adults in the pic fool ya, these were purchased for children. We all "tested" these trucks with the lights on and off. They're VERY bright and seem to roll smoothly. They can maneuver over some small obstacles. The children also had fun with them. If your fun seekers are heavy handed, beware. These are very lightweight. The truck will likely survive a fall from the dinning room table (I'm not going to test that theory) but they feel like they'll definitely fracture under too much pressure. In the end, you'll still have a lot of fun. I mean, the kids will still have a lot of fun...

title: Meh... I'll make it work.
text: Most of the stickers are very small. There's only a slight raise. Quite a few have no adhesive on them (or purhaps a cheap adhesive dried up). I got these because there are all kinds of feminine raised stickers out there. However, it's difficult to find interesting options for my nephew. So, I will make due. Maybe I'll have some Elmer's or hit them with the hot glue gun when using these. ...guess I won't be sticking these on the hand or forehead when the nephew does a great job tho... 😒 Note: they're only easy to remove because the adhesive isn't great.

title: This is a decent tool
text:
I purchased these as an educational tool with play potential. I wanted a fun way of helping twins learn and spell their 1st and last name. I also thought it would be a good tool to trace letters so they can improve their handwriting. Today, I used these with one of the children. My ideas are going to prove fruitful.

I have a few issues that may or may not be of importance to others: The letters are tough for little uncoordinated hands to extract from the box but fine putting them back in (for the most part). The inkpads seem to only have a sheer pigment. I'll have to get different inkpads so that the letter will show up with the 1st stamp. I had to press hard and drag the stamp to get the ink on there solidly. Maybe a little OCD, but the letters are not all centered on the stamp so the letters may create a wave or have too much space between them if stamping out a word or sentence for the academic stuff I want to do with this kit. It'll be fine for creative art activities though. I'll add a photo later.

title: I wish i would have also gotten the lowercase letters when i bought these...
text:
This letter puzzle was a great find. It's good for teaching the alphabet in order and out of order. After our twins learned the alphabet in order, we then began asking them to name letters by their color. We practiced simple skills like "put on red letters" or "take off blue letters." We also ask them to name the letters by the column or reading them backwards from z to a. You can help your child say simple sentences like, "the letter z is orange" or "help me find the letter w."

A few of the letters are tough (for the little ones) to fit in. ...the S is an example... However, it just presented us with an opportunity to share directions like "flip, turn or spin" the letter around.

We have had these over 2 years and the color is still strong and there have been no cracks or splintering of the wood letters or backboard. The individual letters are sturdy. This is a great tool for children with autism or various learning disabilities.

title: Great educational tool
text:
These have been great for labeling, counting (5 of each animal, simple math, comparing animals (color, size, height, which have horns, which can fly, etc...), great for imaginative play (bought stackable cups, the children make little mountains for animals to hop on AND the animals go to "school" and talk about what they learned, etc...) and much more. The color has lasted more than 2 Years now. They're washable. I wash by hand with a lil bit of Dawn in the water. They're strong and sturdy. These are great for any developing mind and especially autistic children.

There was an little chemical odor when I 1st opened the container but it didn't stick around long and it wasn't pungent.

title: Good playful tool for growing minds
text:
I purchased these about 2 years ago. They helped with learning colors, hand eye coordination, counting, comparing (size & height), identifying numbers (numbers printed on the bottom of cups), sorting, imaginative play (the twins use them to make a rocket ship and as mountains when they play with their small animals), and so much more. The four year olds still play with them. I highly recommend stackable for all growing minds and especially autistic children for project base learning.

The cups do have holes vented in the bottom so if you have a child who likes to transfer items from one cup to another, stay close. 1 of ours is fond of pouring juice in them to drink AND plays in the mess when I turn my back. 😉😐😂

title: This is a great tool for engaging the oil ones and labeling
text:
This is a great tool for engaging the oil ones and labeling. Its also good for teaching hand eye coordination and simple commands like turn the car around, pick up, put on and clean up time.

I picked up a few of these puzzles and I like that durability of the wood pieces and the strength of the board itself. The images are applied and not painted to the blocks. I've had these for about 14 months and I've seen no lifting or peeling. The twins just turned 3 a few months ago and there were a favorite toy option for them. Sometimes, I had to send them to nap with their favorite pieces.

I have used a damp paper towel to clean stains. I'm more than satisfied. I purchased the farm animals, shapes, zoo animals and construction sight.

title: Now kids can do marbling just like the pros.
text:
[[VIDEOID:2e7b61347cbcd0c2a7405a8c115f9f8e]] Hotep brothers and sisters and thank you for looking at my review of the Funwins Marbling Paint Kit, Water Art Paint Set, Non-Toxic, Painting on Water, Creative Arts and Crafts for Kids, You will get 6 colors of paint (10ml each), 10 sheets(A5), 1 packets of powder (5g), measuring spoon, 3 drawing pins, paintbrush and comb, tweezers and tray. Totally non-toxic, environmentally friendly and safe.
Although this is a kids set it also could be a nice starter set you bet. The little tray and the tools you can reuse to do more art whenever you choose. I recommend using better paper which you can get anywhere when you're on your art caper. Be sure that when you mix it you mix it right and it's best to let your mixture stand overnight. Now here's a secret that the box doesn't tell and that's how you could mix your own solution very well. There are several methods for making marbled papers. A shallow tray is filled with water, and various kinds of ink or paint colors are carefully applied to the surface with an ink brush. Various additives or surfactant chemicals are used to help float the colors. A drop of "negative" color made of plain water with the addition of surfactant is used to drive the drop of color into a ring. The process is repeated until the surface of the water is covered with concentric rings. The floating colors are then carefully manipulated either by blowing on them directly or through a straw, fanning the colors, or carefully using a human hair to stir the colors. In the 19th century, the Kyoto-based Japanese suminagashi master Tokutaro Yagi developed an alternative method that employed a split piece of bamboo to gently stir the colors, resulting in concentric spiral designs. A sheet of washi paper is then carefully laid onto the water surface to capture the floating design. The paper, which is often made of kozo (paper mulberry), must be unsized and strong enough to withstand being immersed in water without tearing.
Another method of marbling more familiar to Europeans and Americans is made on the surface of a viscous mucilage, known as size or sizing in English. While this method is often referred to as "Turkish marbling" in English and called ebru in modern Turkish, ethnic Turkic peoples were not the only practitioners of the art, as Persian, Tajiks, and people of Indian origin also made these papers. The use of the term Turkish by Europeans is most likely due to both the fact that many first encountered the art in Istanbul, as well as essentialist references to all Muslims as Turks, much as Europeans were referred to as Firengi in Turkish and Persian, which literally means Frankish.
Historic forms of marbling used both organic and inorganic pigments mixed with water for colors, and sizes were traditionally made from gum tragacanth (Astragalus spp.), gum karaya, guar gum, fenugreek (Trigonella foenum-graecum), fleabane, linseed, and psyllium. Since the late 19th century, a boiled extract of the carrageenan-rich alga known as Irish moss (Chondrus crispus), has been employed for sizing. Today, many marblers use powdered carrageenan extracted from various seaweeds. Another plant-derived mucilage is made from sodium alginate. In recent years, a synthetic size made from hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, a common ingredient in instant wallpaper paste, is often used as a size for floating acrylic and oil paints.
In the size-based method, colors made from pigments are mixed with a surfactant such as ox gall. Sometimes, oil or turpentine may be added to a color, to achieve special effects. The colors are then spattered or dropped onto the size, one color after another until there is a dense pattern of several colors. Straw from the broom corn was used to make a kind of whisk for sprinkling the paint, or horsehair to create a kind of drop-brush. Each successive layer of pigment spreads slightly less than the last, and the colors may require additional surfactant to float and uniformly expand. Once the colors are laid down, various tools and implements such as rakes, combs, and styluses are often used in a series of movements to create more intricate designs.
Paper or cloth is often mordanted beforehand with aluminium sulfate (alum) and gently laid onto the floating colors (although methods such as Turkish ebru and Japanese suminagashi do not require mordanting). The colors are thereby transferred and adhered to the surface of the paper or material. The paper or material is then carefully lifted off the size and hung up to dry. Some marblers gently drag the paper over a rod to draw off the excess size. If necessary, excess bleeding colors and sizing can be rinsed off, and then the paper or fabric is allowed to dry. After the print is made, any color residues remaining on the size are carefully skimmed off of the surface, in order to clear it before starting a new pattern.
Contemporary marblers employ a variety of modern materials, some in place of or in combination with the more traditional ones. A wide variety of colors are used today in place of the historic pigment colors. Plastic broom straw can be used instead of broom corn, as well as bamboo sticks, plastic pipettes, and eye droppers to drop the colors on the surface of the size. Ox gall is still commonly used as a surfactant for watercolors and gouache, but synthetic surfactants are used in conjunction with acrylic, PVA, and oil-based paints.

title: Funny easter project for kids, and even adults who love arts and crafts...
text:
[[VIDEOID:eea507c3bc5926cecf15c6c5daa2aea0]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Easy to assemble, instructions provided, but you really don't need it.
* Very neat, very cute, fun idea.
* Complete kit with blanks and markers, and even gold tassels.
* Takes three AA batteries (not included).
* You can switch from rotating the eggs with lights effect, or without lights.
* Nice packaging, so it's giftable.

THE BAD:
------------
* Speed of rotation cannot be adjusted. As is, it seems pretty fast. But I don't think this will be much of a problem. You can always turn it off if you want to add little details to the egg. Only rotate if you're planning to do single color strokes. 5-Stars!

title: Very difficult, no demo to learn from...
text:
THE GOOD:
---------------
* The loops are made of high quality plastic, very sturdy.
* The juggling balls are pretty dense.
* Challenging, difficult, hard... for those who like a good challenge.

THE BAD:
------------
* No instructions, no video demos. Can't find anything on YT either. The closest thing we found was something called the pindaloo. So if you need some help, search "pindaloo juggling" since it's based on the same principe. The only difference is the pindaloo is fully enclosed, so I think it's a little easier to learn, since the ball can't escape the loop. With this "Scoop de loop," the ball easily falls out of the open enclosure.
* The juggling balls are too dense. Was going to give this to my children to play, but these balls can do damage in your home, especially if you have things on display like collectibles, picture frames, etc. So I recommend this for outdoors only.

I'll rate this 3-Stars simply for the lack of information and demo.

title: Perfect Easter gift, this will be the grand prize in our Easter hunt...

title: Super fan RC shark toy with features that are much more convenient compared to competitors...
text:
[[VIDEOID:d37c6342e8e80cfb57344e508fc0db13]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Super fun rc shark toy! For both kids and adults!
* Made of plastic, but nicely put together at this price point.
* Comes with two 1000 mah batteries and extra back-up propellers. I reviewed a competitor shark whose batteries are only 500 mah each.
* Battery compartment designed is superior to other sharks on the market. (Watch my video).
* Remote control uses two AAA batteries, not included.
* Remote control has a demo button, allowing the shark to just move on its own.
* Controls for this remote is more traditional. The shark can go straight by moving the left control stick forward. The control stick on the right moves horizontally left or right for turns. This is much easier for younger kids.

THE BAD:
------------
* Remote control is bland compared to others on the market, but at least it has the basic function of allowing the shark to go straight, unlike the other one I reviewed. (Watch my video).
* No water shooting from the top of Shark feature like the other one I reviewed. (Watch my video).

Overall, this shark is easier to use for younger children, and the battery compartment design is so much more convenient. We'll go 5-Stars! Here's the other shark I compared this to in my video:
https://www.amazon.com/review/R1G84SVKMQ19PQ/ref=cm_cr_srp_d_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8

title: Very fun rc shark, but has inconvenient features compared to others...
text:
[[VIDEOID:9ac4d35bf8bbf42fc7581bddc567188c]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Super fun, very giftable RC Shark toy.
* Made of plastic, but nicely put together at this price point.
* Comes with two 3.7v 500 mah batteries and extra back-up propellers.
* Remote control uses two AA batteries, which are included as well.
* Remote control has a demo button, allowing the shark to just move on its own.
* Remote control also has a spray water button. Press it, and water will spray from the Shark's top.

THE BAD:
------------
* Battery compartment on shark requires the removal of 3 screws. The battery compartment of a competing product was much easier. Watch my video.
* Removing the battery cover from the remote control is a little convoluted. It requires pressing in a dimple, while sliding it out. I found it difficult to do. I have to press with a screw driver with one hand, and slide the cover out with the other hand.
* This Shark does not go straight. This is not a defect, I've seen this type of design in RC cars too. One stick controls the left turn, and one stick controls the right turn. So for it to go straight, you need to constantly balance each control stick. Not ideal for younger kids.

Despite all the bad things I listed, I'll still rate this 4-Stars because of the price point and fun factor. But watch my video. The shark I compare it to in my video is a 5-Star. Here's the other shark I compared this to in my video: https://www.amazon.com/review/R3QXJRAO2EAZ63/ref=cm_cr_srp_d_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8

title: Nice kit for your child to test the waters of stop motion animation...
text:
[[VIDEOID:f60c8d38ecf6f303c318aed73eb3bcd5]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* All in one kit to get you started in stop motion animation.
* Educational, and fun.

THE BAD:
------------
* First off, app will be hit or miss. How is it a miss for Google Pixel Pro 6, but a hit for our dinosaur Oneplus 5t? Very basic app that is children friendly, but you'll still need to do a run-through with them first.
* Requires a lot of patience. 10 to 30 minutes of work and posing, for a few seconds of video.
* Lighting can be an issue. The best lighting is natural light. If your home is not naturally lit, and you turn on artificial lights, it can cause glares that will show up in the video because the cardboards are very glossy.
* Cardboard studio has gaps where light will seep in. This can also show in the video. You'll need to tape it shut.
* Camera tripod is terrible.
* The Stickbot takes a lot of patience to pose. Their rubber band joints are very confusing to sort out.

In conclusion... honestly, I am very surprised by the popularity of this brand. Because to get started in stop motion, you don't need this kit. You can get more real estate by getting those foam or thick boards from dollar stores. They have all sorts of colors, and green is definitely available. Or, you can buy green muslim backdrops. You can use Legos, Playmobils, any type of action figure at all, it doesn't need to be stickbots. And you can use any apps at all besides the Stickbot app, which is woefully lacking in features. So, why use this kit? I guess the one advantage they have is the Stickbot suction feet and hands. They will stay in place, which makes this ideal for children. Simply to let your children learn on their own, knowing that the video they make will be terrible. LOL! But once you see that they have a sincere interest, then perhaps you can buy them better accessories. The video clip in this review is by my 7 yr old daughter. I was surprised when she showed it to me. It's terrible, but pretty good for a 7 yr old with little patience. LOL! We'll go 3-Stars overall.

title: Super fun, we look like human hamsters...
text:
THE GOOD:
---------------
* Super huge, lots of fun!
* You need a high quality inflator to get a completely round donut. At first, I was using my Ryobi inflator which was more for basketballs and tires. Then I used a mini rechargeable inflator that was specifically made for pool inflatables. Neither of them would get this to a donut shape. Once enough air is inside, you can see it starts to take an oval shape, and you can see the bends and the creases. Weak inflators will not get by these creases. Air is just forced to escape back out where the plug input is. No matter how long I let it run. Then the very next day, I got in the mail, a 25 psi Sup Air Pump. The kind people take to the beaches to pump up their paddle boards. This guy pumped up the rider into a completely round donut and it was super fast.
* Small supply of vinyl patch is included.

THE BAD:
------------
* It takes just 2 to 3 sessions with little kids ages 7 to 10 to already do damage to this thing. LOL! We got two holes already, which I patched up with the provided adhesive vinyl.
* One of the wheels is already peeling from the center seat. The good thing is that, this is not a hole. Because there are 3 air plug locations. Each wheel and the center seat have their own plugs. So you're blowing up three separate components. In the event that the vinyl completely tears and all 3 components are separated, they can still be individually used. As long as the seams are tearing along the perforation, each component is still sealed. It just won't be as fun if it's no longer a hamster wheel. LOL!

I'll rate this 4-Stars overall! I recommend having a good supply of vinyl patch. Just patch it up every time you get a hole. It's too expensive and too fun to just throw away.

title: Super cool, super fun, super retro...
text:
[[VIDEOID:8a2a841129f89fa27807cb1af4940424]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* 9900 games... wow!
* The Pandora arcade has been around for awhile now, so you're getting one of their more powerful, and polished generations.
* Build quality is not bad. The acrylic glass at the top is very nice.
* Sticks and buttons are probably not high end Sanwa stuff, but they are good enough for casual gamers, and par for the course at this price range.
* HDMI and VGA outputs. I've read negative comments by others about the VGA, but I think that's because they're not familiar with this hobby. Hardcore retro gamers want and appreciate the VGA port because then they can use it with CRT monitors. They actually prefer it over HDMI because visually, CRTs are more arcade accurate. I don't care. I'm only a casual gamer, but I'm just letting you know why it's there.
* Many games, you're offered game saves, so you can continue next time where you left off. But I didn't see this offered for every game I tried. Some didn't offer it.
* Plenty of 4 player games are available, just plug in a usb gamepad. You have two usb ports in the back. Watch my video for tips. Out the box, the 3rd and 4th player usb ports do not work. You need to go into the settings. I have two kids, so it was important for me to figure this out. LOL!
* Customer service was very quick and responsive. I was trying to get 3rd and 4th player to work, and I figured it out before they got back to me, but they did get back to me the very next day.

THE BAD:
------------
* Not all the games function properly. For example, Rampage World Tour has no audio. Many games seem to be duplicates, or unnecessary duplicates. Still, there are 9900 titles, so there will be plenty to keep you happy.
* Don't think you can turn off internal speakers. There is a volume rocker in the back, but if you lower this rocker, not only does the internal speaker go down, but whatever audio system you're connected to will go down too. I talk about this in my video.

I think this is a 5 star product. Because the prices for these things have gone down, while the specs have gone up. If you're jumping in now, you're getting a more powerful system at a lower price than if you had jumped in 5 yrs ago. I held out. I went the retropie route. I bought an Xarcade stick and built retropie with a raspberry pi. You ultimately have a better system tailored to your liking, but the raspberry pi won't be inside the arcade stick like this Pandora system. Well, it could be, it would just take more work. Building a retro pie will end up costing more, as well as being time consuming because there is a big learning curve if you've never built one, not to mention knowing how to get the games. You can go through all that, or get yourself one of these Pandora systems and start playing immediately! 5-Stars.

title: Tiny building blocks at a huge cost...

THE BAD:

The problem is the price. It doesn't feel like you're getting much material, and if families have to choose between one or the other, I don't think these things are competitive against the establishment like Legos. For the same price, you can do a lot more with Legos. I'll go 4-Stars.

title: So much to learn, but so cool, we are living in the future...
text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Very high quality components. Each piece has good weight to it.
* What you build is limited only by your imagination, and your patience to code and program.
* Two pre-programmed robots out the box in BIC and BAC. You can only choose to build one version at a time though. They are very lively, and seem to react to the environment.
* From the Clicbot app, you will have access to other creations that you can build. The section for this is called "THE PLAYGROUND." To get instructions for a robot you want to build, you need to hit "PLAY." You can then build simply looking at the completed robot, or tap to switch to step by step instructions.
* If you can afford it, the Maker Kit is definitely the one to get. In the app, you can keep a tally of all the components you have in "MY MODULES." Underneath the "PLAY" button for any particular robot, there will be a message that says "Module is insufficient, click to refresh." Click refresh, and you'll get to the MY MODULES tracker. Here, you can update all the modules you have, so that when you're interested in building any other robot, it'll know if you have enough for the project.
* Lots of fun with the family. Get you children into robotics and coding.

THE BAD:
------------
* As we learn more and more, I'll update, but for now, here are some noteworthy things.
* It seems Bac and Bic are the only builds that have any sort of A.I. I've built one other robot called "Little Cutie," and I was disappointed that all the personalities of Bac or Bic were gone. They are simply RC robots when you make these other builds. You control them from your App. Like I said, I've only built one. I could be wrong, there could be AI in other builds. I'll be sure to update.
* The APP has a lot going on, it's cluttered. But spend some time in it, and I think you'll get used to it.
* The process of disassembling or removing a module is nerve racking. There is nothing in the manual, or the app that shows you how to remove modules properly. At least, I haven't found it. But you are basically yanking the pieces apart. I feel like something is going to break every time I remove a module.
* The sticky pads to mount the base for "BAC" is a one time use pad. Something that should have been mentioned in the manual. We installed on the tile floor, and wanted to move him, but it was very difficult to budge. Ultimately, we were able to remove the base, and placed him at a different location, but the base no longer could support BAC, he kept falling. However, we found 20 other sticky pads in the accessories box. Why would that many be included? That's when we realize it's must be a one time use deal. They even sell it on their site, 20 pieces for $20 bucks. So if you don't want to waste sticky pads, I recommend choosing a go-to location for Bac, a place were you rarely have to move the base. The good thing is you can remove Bac and all his components to build other things. Just don't remove the base.
* The price.... yikes! I never even heard of Clicbot before this. I just accidentally bumped into this product while browsing Vine. This isn't something you buy to see if your kids have an interest in coding and robots. This is something you buy KNOWING they have a sincere interest.

ADVICE ON INITIAL BAC OR BIC BUILD:
----------------------------------------------
* The initial process of putting together BAC or BIC can be confusing because the app takes you to a certain point, then it tells you that BAC will take over from his LCD screen, and it wants you to follow those instructions. But the confusion was BAC's screen wants to UPDATE, but then it also says, "Wait till the entire robot is completed before updating," so that all modules can be updated at the same time. So the screen is not giving me any instructions cause it's waiting for the entire body to be built. But at the same time, the app no longer is giving instructions either cause it says to follow Bac. LOL! Ultimately, what I realized is that you go ahead and update anyways. BAC's screen will ask for a confirmation if the entire robot has been assembled, this is where you lie and say YES, ASSEMBLED. LOL! But once it updates the module, it'll know it isn't complete, and it'll give you the next step. Once you connect the next module, go ahead and update again. You're just updating the modules one by one as you're building it. There was a lot of confusion, but somehow we got through and built BAC. I think the company needs to go back to the drawing board on this initial process.

FUTURE FIRMWARE SUGGESTIONS:
------------------------------------------
* Alexa, Siri, Google Assistant integration, or something independent like what Vector by Anki has.
* They should make a tempered glass screen protector for the screen, or even a basic film protector.
* Remote viewing utilizing the onboard camera. This way you can control the robot around the house and see what he sees. I can do this with Vector, but it wasn't something Anki or Digital Dreams Lab did. It was accomplished by 3rd party developers. So I know this is something the Clicbot team can absolutely do if they wanted to.

This was our first day playing with it, and I just wanted to get a review up. I will definitely update as I learn more. Overall, this is still 5-Stars because it is serious tech. If I time travelled from the 1980's to 2022, I would be blown away by this. We are living in the future. 5-Stars.

title: An amazing gift set, amazing quality, and amazing customer service...

title: Summer can't come quick enough...
text:
REVIEW UPDATE JUNE 30, 2022:
---------------------------------------
* We were finally able to take this tank for a spin. It is indeed super fun. But here are 3 noteworthy things:

1.) It is gigantic, adult supervision is required to make sure kids get in and out of it safely. Never allow them to stand up to get out. Buoyancy can cause them to flip and hit the side of the pool cement. So make sure they simply crawl off the tank slowly and safely, like rolling out of bed. LOL!
2.) It takes forever to blow it up, even with an electronic inflator. So if you want to avoid anxious kids, then prepare it the day before, or at least 30 minutes before swim time.
3.) The water gun is not as I imagined. There is no trigger. It's a pump action. A clear straw/pipe dangles through the bottom into the pool, so you can constantly pump water. It is difficult for little children. So the idea that whoever is in the tank has the advantage is wrong. LOL! In our pool, we all have water guns, and whoever is in the tank becomes the target. LOL! Nevertheless, it's still very fun, and the 5-Star rating is justified.

ORIGINAL REVIEW MAY 4th, 2022:
----------------------------------------

THE GOOD:
---------------
* Seems like super fun!
* 61"x44"x24" is a very substantial size. So this is not for little above ground pools.
* The vinyl feels pretty standard. It did not feel thin or cheap.
* Everything seems to be complete. It even included little repair stickers in case you get holes.

THE BAD:
------------
* Well, we won't exactly know yet until the summer. I got this for the upcoming summer, and I'll be sure to update. My kids can't wait. For now, gotta give it 5-Stars.

title: This is a big improvement from their previous release...
text:
There already exist a paperback 5 book series called, "Monster School Diaries" by Kid-Fi Media on Amazon. However, there are 4 differences:

However, with the improvements, corrections, as well as a lower price, this version is 5-Stars.

title: The final results are beautiful, it is absolutely worth the effort...
text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* The brochure in the box will direct you to instructionweb, where you will download the manual via PDF. They'll ask you to enter the code on the sku label of your box. Don't enter the actual sku, you'll want to input "P29501."
* All the lights work! That's the biggest fear with kits like these. But mine was perfect! You are advised to test all the lights too before you start. If there are any that are defective, you should contact the seller for replacements before you get started.
* This will take several hours. You'll need mental stamina to follow the instructions. This isn't something you can just casually do while watching TV. It's not difficult or anything, it just requires a lot of focus and attention to details. Well, to be honest, I had the NBA playoffs on. LOL! But with sports, you can just hear, you don't have to watch. I was completely zoned in on this project.
* You can power it by connecting a usb cable, or using a AA battery pack. Both options are provided.
* The end result is absolutely worth it. I love how the torch light slowly flickers, a very nice touch. I included a lot of pictures to show you how involved the process is. This way, you can decide whether or not you want to pursue this project.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all. 5-Stars!

title: Awesome toy, as well as multiplication supplement for grade school children...
text: Kids love pop it fidgets, so why not have them brush up on their multiplication skills at the same time? My kid is only learning up to 10 from her school right now, so I'm glad this thing goes up to 13. Be sure to explain why the answer is the answer, otherwise this short-cut chart could actually be detrimental. What is 9x8? She'll locate the 72, but I would then explain using marbles that there are 9 groups of 8 marbles, or 8 groups of 9 marbles. If you add them up, there are 72 marbles total. Anyway, this thing is 5-Stars!

title: Awesome, customizable fidget roulette wheel, just like the Mystic Seer...
text:
[[VIDEOID:c81ae3ef24867e12ca563b82c398c592]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* There is just something satisfactory about spinning objects. LOL!
* The spin function is very smooth, glides perfectly.
* Comes with 8 general terms, but the wheels are customizable with templates from their website. I plan to make plates with answers exactly like the Mystic Seer in the Twilight Zone.
* Can use as keychain or Christmas ornament.

HOW TO CUSTOMIZE:
--------------------------
* Mine did not come with any instructions, but I contacted the sellers and here are the instructions:

Step 1: Twist the top and bottom shell to open the Fidget roulette
Step 2: Remove the Sticker with our logo. (It will reveal a screw)
Step 3: Remove the screw while holding the front dial with the “?” (This will give you access to the Answer Wheel)
Step 4: Go to Fidgetroulette.com , download the Answer Wheel you desire and print it (If you don't have sticker paper available, you can use regular paper and use paper glue)
Step 5: put it back together and have fun!

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all, this is really fun. Watch my video to see how it does in place of the Mystic Seer in the Twilight Zone episode. LOL! 5-Stars.

title: Nice idea, good quality books, but could use some improvements...
text:
THE GOOD:
---------------
* I reviewed one of their earlier releases, Hansel and Gretel, and it seems they took one of my suggestions to heart. The instructions are now in the front! In Hansel and Gretel, the instructions were in the back. When you read a book, you don't flip to the back immediately, so it was not instinctual to go look for instructions in the back. I had to search YT to learn how to use the book. Now, they put the instructions in the front! Bravo!
* There seems to be variations in packaging. There is no cardboard box for "the Ants and the Grasshopper" like there was for "the Three Bears." Instead, there is a simpler insert that wraps the front board cover, almost like a dust jacket, but only for the front cover. Anyway, this insert shows the operational instructions.
* They still kept the instructions in the back pages of the book. So now it's in the front and the back, so you can't miss it.
* Fun for the kids. They love reading these books and doing their own voices.
* Nifty technology, and very giftable.
* Register for 1 year warranty where you can replace your book should you have any issues.
* Battery compartment in the back takes 3 AAA batteries (included). You'll need a small screwdriver to get to it. There is also a switch inside. You flip this switch if you don't want anybody messing with the recording. But don't do it! Let your kids have fun recording over and over. It's a hassle to bring out a little screw driver every time they want to record.

THE BAD:
------------
* Still not a great value proposition at $40 a pop.
* Still finicky. I said above this is nifty technology, but probably can still use improvements. You're pressing flat sensors on paper. Sometimes it registers, sometimes it doesn't and you have to keep pressing. Perhaps with more force, at an angle, etc. Like getting your smartphone to register your fingerprint. LOL! I'll place the percentage at about 70% success rate. 3 out of 10 times, you'll have to keep pressing. So it's not terrible.

I used to rate this 3-Stars, but now that I understand it more, I'm going 4-Stars overall.

title: If the connector breaks, the eggs will have sharp protruding plastics...
text:
[[VIDEOID:42df10e13a3ec218ca0139ac6111e1f8]] THE GOOD:

title: I was expecting Nerf to put more thought into this...
text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Makes a kid's room look cooler.
* Makes tidying up laundry fun.
* Ball and pump included.
* Easy over the door hanger.
* Laundry bag has a zipper at the bottom, so you can dump the clothes into a different basket instead of having to unhook actual bag. (But more on this below)

THE BAD:
------------
* I don't know what I was expecting, but I was underwhelmed. It doesn't seem much thought was put into this. I expected an easy system for taking down and putting back up the bag. But that wasn't what Nerf had in mind, that is why they designed a zipper at the bottom of the bag. They know it's a hassle to take down the bag. But it seems ridiculous to have to use a different laundry basket when it's time to actually take out the laundry. LOL! The reason it would be a hassle to take down the bag is because there are 4 drawstring loops on the bag. Two of them hang on dedicated hooks in the back of the backboard. The two front loops is where the hassle comes into play. There are no dedicated hooks for these. You have to squeeze them into the rim's net hooks, which are already occupied by the basketball net. That's why I say squeeze, it's already tight due to the net. BTW, they don't tell you this in the manual. It's something you just logically figure out yourself. There is nowhere else to hang those loops other than to share them with the rim's net hooks. If they would just add two more dedicated hooks for the bag somewhere in the front of the rim, taking down the bag would be easy.
* The reason why I'm harping about this or expected more is because we already have higher quality official NBA hoops that are made for over the door too. I had already thought of hanging a bag with drawstrings and force it to share the rim's net hooks. I actually have thought of that before, and I didn't do it. I thought this product that was specifically made for this purpose would provide a better solution. It did not, it is almost the same solution I had in mine. LOL!
* I will come up with a solution that will make it easy to take down and put back up the bag... Velcro comes to mine.

3-Stars.

title: It's like having a personal coach, but you have to be fond of retro toys and have patience...
text:

title: One of the best looking sabers out there, but charging issues may be common...
text:
[[VIDEOID:a47326bb48b328d18558c86fcccc38a1]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Very high quality. The handle alone is 12.4 ounces.
* USB-C charging port.
* Belt clip included.
* Decorative blade plug is included. This is cool if you just want to display the handle without the blade. You can cap off your handle with this decorative plug.
* Bottom of the hilt is a decorative speaker cap instead of a pommel/coupling.
* Hilt is 1-1/4 inch. This will connect with other 1.25 inch handles to create a duo saber. Another dominant size on the market is a smaller 1 and 1/8th diameter version. This one will not thread onto 1.25 hilts, so to create duo sabers with different brands, be sure the hilts are the same size.
* All the special effects are pretty much standard: Lock up effect, changing colors, steady, pulse, unstable, etc. This version also has quotes. Watch my video to see a demo

THE BAD:
------------
* Pommel or coupling is not included. As mentioned above, bottom of the hilt is a decorative speaker cap. When you remove this speaker cap, the bottom of this hilt will be male. So to create the duo saber, your other saber should have a coupling so that it's female.
* My light saber did not charge properly out the box. When you plug it in to charge, it'll loudly announce, "Charging!" Then the red light will blink slowly. When it is complete, it will say, "READY," and the red light will be stable, no blinking. Chances are you're not going to be present when the saber says READY. But as long as you see the red light is stable and not blinking, then you'll know it's fully charged. My issue was that after 10 hrs of charging, the red light was still blinking slowly, and the saber wouldn't turn on. I contacted customer support and they had a solution ready to go. So this seems like a common problem. I talk about this at the end of my video, so watch it if you have a charging issue. My saber is charging properly now. So the word to describe this saber is, finicky.

I'll give this an overall rating of 4-Stars.

title: Super cool unique project from a very proactive company...
text:
[[VIDEOID:cd131599fe352cad31ef03a30268e27c]] NOV 16, 2021 UPDATE:
----------------------------
* This is a very proactive company. Upon reading my review, they reached out to me to explain that some of their inventory did not have English manuals. They've since attached the English manual via PDF under the "Product guides and documents" section of the Amazon listing. After looking at the English manual, it will definitely help us finish this project. I said in my original review, this would be a 5 star product if not for the lack of instructions, so now there is. So I will change my rating. Thank you very much.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
----------------------

THE GOOD:
--------------
* High quality metal components.
* High quality tools included.
* Very cool, giftable packaging.

THE BAD:
-----------
* I'm very curious by the other great reviews that are not mentioning the elephant in the room. The instructions are not in English! Technically, you can get away with just looking at the pictures, but it will be a strain for your eyes. You'll need to scan the pictures and zoom in for more clarity to see where exactly the nuts and bolts are going.
* Throughout the manual, there are important notes they want you to understand. These tips and notes are highlighted in red with an exclamation mark! Unfortunately, you won't understand what's so important. LOL!
* Think this will be a cool project to spend some time with your kid? Think again.
* Watch my video to understand my annoyance. This could be 5-Stars, but I'm going 3 for the lack of instructions.

text:
[[VIDEOID:d41ea8b6e0b1130f66ebd0968fb1f602]] THE GOOD:
--------------

THE BAD:
------------
